channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Businesses pay back wage subsidy: 'It's not a time to be greedy'
item.description: The government's wage subsidy scheme has been paid to nearly 1000 companies who should not have received it.

item.title: Disability employer Altus' redundancy package: a story with no winners
item.description: Lockdown has led Altus Enterprises to make 137 of its disabled employees redundant, leaving workers and company leadership alike heartbroken.

item.title: 'We need to continue to stick to the rules' - Police Commissioner
item.description: Police have dealt with 4452 breaches since the lockdown began, including 423 in the past 24 hours. Watch the latest update from the Police Commissioner and Civil Defence director here.

item.title: As it happened: Latest Covid-19 news from NZ and around the world
item.description: The number of new cases of Covid-19 in New Zealand continues to fall, but the death toll is still on the rise. See how the day unfolded with RNZ's live blog.

item.title: Family considers legal action against cruise operator after man dies
item.description: The family of a couple who caught Covid-19 on a cruise are considering legal action against the ship's operator Royal Caribbean.

item.title: Apology to family after Invercargill woman dies of Covid-19
item.description: A 62-year-old Invercargill woman has died in Dunedin Hospital, with the director general of health apologising to the family after her condition was mistakenly described as stable.

item.title: Len Lye Centre co-directors quit to return home
item.description: The first-ever co-directors of the Govett-Brewster Art Gallery / Len Lye Centre in New Plymouth have quit after barely a year in the job.

item.title: Covid-19: Three new cases in NZ, two further deaths reported
item.description: Three new cases of Covid-19 have been reported in NZ in the past 24 hours, with the Health Ministry also confirming two further deaths from the coronavirus.

item.title: Testing-for-all centre in Auckland reaching Pasifika communities
item.description: A Covid-19 centre in South Auckland tested 300 people not showing any symptoms of the virus today in a bid to reach at-risk Pacific communities.

item.title: Covid-19: High school students create working ventilator from wood, lego
item.description: A group of high school students have created a low-cost ventilator using pieces of wood, lego, and a power drill.

item.title: Courts to open to public in alert level 3
item.description: Courts will be open to the public under alert level 3, but jury trials will remain suspended for a few more months.

item.title: Govt support package offers little to newspapers
item.description: Media companies hit hard by plummeting advertising revenue since the start of Covid-19 level 4 lockdown have been given a lifeline, but newspapers were the bottom of the heap.

item.title: Cheaper fuel good news for busy trucking firms during Covid-19 restrictions
item.description: The head of New Zealand's Road Transport Forum says trucking firms are starting to see the benefit of a drop in fuel prices.

item.title: Police officer punching boy, 13, unjustifed, watchdog finds
item.description: A police officer unjustifiably punched a small 13-year-old boy multiple times in the ribs during an arrest, the Independent Police Conduct Authority has found.

item.title: Hunting to be allowed on private land under Covid-19 alert level 3
item.description: Hunters will be able to resume their activities under level 3 as long as they have permission from the land owner, but this does not extend to public conservation land.

item.title: Flight returning Kiwis stranded in India arrives on Saturday
item.description: The first flight bringing New Zealanders stranded in India home will touch down in Auckland on Saturday.

item.title: Controversial tech firm Palantir had talks with govt on Covid-19
item.description: The secretive US data-mining firm Palantir founded by Silicon Valley billionaire and NZ citizen Peter Thiel has had talks with the government here about combating Covid-19.

item.title: Taranaki seabed mining opponents ready to stop 'risky extractive practice' again
item.description: Opponents of a bid to mine millions of tonnes of ironsands off the coast of Taranaki say they will continue to fight the proposal.
